revised_title: The Fading of Water-Colour Pigments and the Action of Ozone
tldr: The author conducted experiments to study the fading of water-colour pigments and found that the presence of moisture and oxygen is essential for the change to occur. They discovered that mineral colours are more stable than vegetable colours and that the spectrum colours that cause fading are mainly at the blue end. The introduction of an active oxidizing agent, such as ozone, into the atmosphere can cause fading similar to prolonged exposure to light. The author concludes that the life of colours will be longer in an atmosphere free from an active oxidizing agent.
